metadata.titleEn: China regional atmospheric driving dataset based on geostationary satellites and reanalysis data (2005-2010)
metadata.description:
Based on the geostationary satellites and reanalysis data, the China Regional Atmospheric Driving Dataset is a set of atmospheric driving data sets with high spatiotemporal resolution prepared by the China Meteorological Administration, with a spatial resolution of 0.1 ° × 0.1 ° and a temporal resolution of 1 Hours, covering a range of 75 ° -135 ° east longitude and 15 ° -55 ° north latitude, include 6 elements of near-surface temperature, relative humidity, ground pressure, near-surface wind speed, incident solar radiation on the ground, and ground precipitation rate. The preparation process of precipitation products is as follows: The 6-hour cumulative precipitation estimated from the multi-channel data of the China Fengyun-2 geostationary satellite is integrated with the 6-hour cumulative precipitation from conventional ground observations to obtain 6-hour cumulative precipitation spatial distribution data, and then use the high-resolution cloud classification information retrieved from the multi-channel inversion of the geostationary satellites determines the interpolation time weight of the cumulative precipitation and obtains an estimated one-hour cumulative precipitation. The preparation process of the radiation data is as follows: The surface incident solar radiation based on FY-2C, uses the radiation transmission model DISORT (Discrete Ordinates Radiative Transfer Program for a Multi-Layered Plane-parallel Medium) to calculate the radiation transmission and obtains the data of surface incident solar radiation in China. Preparation process of other elements: The space and time interpolation method is used for the NCEP reanalysis data of 1.0 ° × 1.0 ° to obtain driving factors such as near-surface air temperature, relative humidity, ground pressure, and near-surface wind speed of 0.1 ° × 0.1 ° per hour.
Physical meaning of each variable:
Meteorological Elements || Variable Name || Unit || Physical Meaning
| Surface temperature || TBOT || K || Surface temperature (2m)
| Surface pressure || PSRF || Pa || Surface pressure
| Relative humidity on the ground || RH || kg / kg || Relative humidity near the ground (2m)
| Wind speed on the ground || WIND || m / s || Wind speed near the ground (anemometer height)
| Surface incident solar radiation || FSDS || W / m2 || Surface incident solar radiation
| Precipitation Rate || PRECTmms || mm / hr || Precipitation Rate
For more information, see the data documentation published with the data.

background: Soil moisture plays an important role in land-atmosphere interactions. It is an important geophysical parameter in research on climate, hydrology, agriculture, and forestry. Soil moisture has important climatic effects by influencing ground evapotranspiration, runoff, surface reflectivity, surface emissivity, surface sensible heat, and latent heat flux. At the global scale, the extent of its influence on the atmosphere is second only to that of sea surface temperature. Soil moisture affects matter and energy balances between land and atmosphere through influencing moisture flux, sensible heat, and latent heat flux. Accurate estimates of the spatial and temporal distribution of soil moisture are of vital importance to further understanding the ecological and physical processes of land and land-atmosphere interactions, and are of great importance in the research and application of meteorology in environmental management, ecology, hydrology, and agriculture. Soil moisture information can currently be acquired with the following methods: regular and field observations, satellite remote sensing, and land hydrological modeling and simulation. However, soil moisture observations based on satellite remote sensing are also problematic. Precision of soil moisture inversion is related to soil type, ground surface roughness, and vegetation coverage. The uncertainty in these parameters results in inversion errors and insufficient temporal and spatial resolutions. Soil moisture obtained through land hydrological modeling simulation and calculation has good temporal frequency and spatial distribution. However, its precision is influenced greatly by model structure and input data. Data assimilation methods used currently in atmospheric, marine, and land data assimilation systems include mainly the optimal interpolation method, 3-D variation method, 4-D variation method, Kalman filter, and EnKF. EnKF is an assimilation method used widely in land model assimilation systems, and uses the Monte Carlo method (overall integration method) to calculate predicted error covariance of the state.

Yang et al. [6] developed an automatic rating system used to estimate moisture and energy balances of soil by assimilating AMSR-E vertical polarization 6.9 and 18.7 GHz luminance temperature data. Tian et al. [7–13], Zhang et al. [14, 15], and Jia et. al. [16] researched the improvement of land data assimilation methods and the rating of microwave luminance temperature assimilation observation operator models.

The land surface model is the core of the land data assimilation system. The CLM3.0 model is designed mainly for coupling with the atmospheric numerical model and provides the surface albedo (direct and scattered light within the visible and infrared bands), upward long-wave radiation, sensible heat flux, latent heat flux, water vapor flux, and east-to-west and south-to-north surface stress needed by the atmospheric model. One of the difficulties preventing us from improving the land model simulation precision is the lack of long-term, high-resolution, observational atmospheric driving data. The advanced microwave scanning radiometer (AMSR-E) carried by EOS/Aqua is the world's first sensor capable of providing soil moisture service outputs at the global scale.
research objective: This paper presents a China Land Soil Moisture Data Assimilation System (CLSMDAS) based on EnKF and land process models, and results of the application of this system in the China Land Soil Moisture Data Assimilation tests.

This paper explains the composition of the China Land Soil Moisture Data Assimilation System (CLSMDAS), processing methods and quality inspection of atmospheric driving data, the performance test of CLSMDAS with single-point observation data, error analysis of observed soil moisture data, and design, and analysis of the CLSMDAS method based on soil water model and station data.

In this paper, inverted precipitation and ground-incident solar radiation products acquired through high spatial and temporal resolution FY2C satellite data were introduced and combined with the NCEP reanalysis data to establish a set of high-quality atmospheric driving data which covers the Chinese region.
challenges: One of the difficulties preventing us from improving the land model simulation precision is the lack of long-term, high-resolution, observational atmospheric driving data. Due to insufficient available ground-level observation soil moisture data, the large error in observed soil moisture, and the inherent high variability of the spatial distribution of soil moisture, it is difficult to verify the assimilated soil moisture data.
methods: The CLSMDAS established in this paper was used to carry out a soil moisture data assimilation sensitivity experiment. We downloaded and processed AMSR-E daily output data between 2004 and 2007 and used regular nationwide soil moisture observation data, detailed soil moisture observation data from Inner Mongolia and Henan Province, and AMSR-E inverted soil moisture data for a comparative analysis. After CLSMDAS was established, first we used single-point observation data acquired from ecological stations for the land soil moisture data assimilation experiment and analyzed the performance of this assimilation system. In this paper, the ground-based observation data provided by newly-built climatic observation stations of China Meteorological Administration was used for a comparative verification of the FY2C ground-incident solar radiation data between July 2005 and June 2009.
dataset: FY2C/D/E satellite precipitation estimate outputs can be downloaded free of charge from the website of the China Satellite Data Service Center (http://satellite.cma.gov.cn/). The atmospheric driving data include: atmospheric temperature, relative humidity at 2 m altitude, wind speed, atmospheric pressure, and precipitation; surface short-wave radiation and 10 cm soil moisture data observed at ground level. The observation data were AMSR-E inverted soil moisture data downloaded from NASA’s official website (http://nsidc.org/data/amsre/).
findings: Both simulation and assimilation results of the land model reflected reasonably the temporal-spatial distribution of soil moisture. The assimilated soil moisture distribution matches very well with severe summer droughts in Chongqing and Sichuan Province in August 2006, the worst since the foundation of the People’s Republic of China in 1949. It also matches drought regions that occurred in eastern Hubei and southern Guangxi in September.

Analysis of the assimilation experiment between June and September 2006 shows that the CLSMDAS soil moisture distribution is consistent with soil moisture observed on the ground. The CLSMDAS soil moisture distribution on August 18, 2006 showed significantly lower soil moisture values in drought regions of Chongqing and Sichuan than in surrounding regions.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to improve the precision of soil moisture inversion when dealing with parameters like soil type and vegetation coverage?
Example.Answer: Soil moisture observations based on satellite remote sensing can be problematic due to precision issues related to soil type, ground surface roughness, and vegetation coverage. The uncertainty in these parameters results in inversion errors and insufficient temporal and spatial resolutions.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a challenge faced when attempting to verify assimilated soil moisture data using ground-level observations?
Example.Answer: One of the difficulties in verifying assimilated soil moisture data is the lack of long-term, high-resolution, observational atmospheric driving data, coupled with insufficient ground-level observation soil moisture data and the large error in observed soil moisture, making it difficult to verify the assimilated data.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that combines satellite data for the estimation of atmospheric driving factors such as precipitation and solar radiation over large regions?
Example.Answer: Inverted precipitation and ground-incident solar radiation products acquired through high spatial and temporal resolution FY2C satellite data, combined with NCEP reanalysis data, were used to establish high-quality atmospheric driving data covering the Chinese region.

Feature Specification.Answer: high spatial resolution of 0.1°×0.1°, temporal resolution of 1 hour, range of 75°-135°E in longitude, range of 15°-55°N in latitude, near-surface temperature, relative humidity, surface pressure, near-surface wind speed, surface incident solar radiation, precipitation rate

Feature Specification.Answer: data assimilation methods, Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF), Monte Carlo method, predicted error covariance

Feature Specification.Question: What methods are used to integrate satellite data with ground observations for precipitation estimation in atmospheric datasets?
Feature Specification.Answer: six-hour cumulative precipitation estimates, high-resolution cloud classification information, one-hour cumulative precipitation estimates

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'high-resolution observational atmospheric driving data' in meteorological research?
Definition.Answer: High-resolution observational atmospheric driving data are crucial for improving the precision of land model simulations. They provide detailed temporal and spatial information needed to accurately simulate land-atmosphere interactions, which are important for understanding ecological and physical processes and for applications in meteorology, environmental management, ecology, hydrology, and agriculture.

Definition.Question: How is 'soil moisture inversion' carried out using satellite remote sensing?
Definition.Answer: Soil moisture inversion using satellite remote sensing involves the use of sensors like the AMSR-E, which captures luminance temperature data at different frequencies. The precision of this inversion is affected by factors such as soil type, surface roughness, and vegetation coverage. These satellite-based observations are combined with models to provide spatial and temporal estimates of soil moisture.

Comparison.Question: How do satellite remote sensing methods for soil moisture data collection compare to land hydrological modeling in terms of temporal and spatial resolution?
Comparison.Answer: Satellite remote sensing methods provide data influenced by soil type, surface roughness, and vegetation, which can result in inversion errors and insufficient temporal and spatial resolutions. In contrast, land hydrological modeling offers good temporal frequency and spatial distribution, though its accuracy is heavily dependent on model structure and input data.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do atmospheric driving data derived from geostationary satellites differ from those obtained through conventional reanalysis data in terms of preparation and resolution?
Comparison.Answer: Atmospheric driving data from geostationary satellites, such as FY-2C, involve high-resolution cloud classification for temporal interpolation, offering 0.1°×0.1° spatial and 1-hour temporal resolutions. On the other hand, conventional reanalysis data, like NCEP, are downscaled from 1.0°×1.0° using spatial and temporal interpolation methods to achieve similar resolutions.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the challenges faced by soil moisture data assimilation systems and satellite remote sensing in terms of data accuracy and verification?
Comparison.Answer: Both soil moisture data assimilation systems and satellite remote sensing face challenges related to data accuracy and verification. Assimilation systems struggle with the lack of long-term, high-resolution observational atmospheric data and verification difficulties due to spatial variability. Similarly, satellite remote sensing is limited by inversion errors due to variability in soil type, surface roughness, and vegetation coverage, affecting data precision.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the development of high-resolution atmospheric driving data influence land-atmosphere interaction research?
Interpretation.Answer: High-resolution atmospheric driving data can enhance the simulation precision of land models by providing detailed inputs such as temperature, humidity, and solar radiation. This can lead to better understanding and modeling of land-atmosphere interactions, as demonstrated by the use of FY-2C satellite data combined with NCEP reanalysis for research in China.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary causes of errors in soil moisture inversion when using satellite remote sensing, and how do these factors affect the accuracy of data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The primary causes of errors in soil moisture inversion using satellite remote sensing include soil type, ground surface roughness, and vegetation coverage. These factors influence the precision of soil moisture inversion by introducing uncertainties in the data, leading to inversion errors and insufficient temporal and spatial resolutions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to improve the precision of land model simulations without long-term, high-resolution observational atmospheric driving data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Improving the precision of land model simulations is challenging due to the lack of long-term, high-resolution observational atmospheric driving data. This absence hinders the ability to accurately simulate land-atmosphere interactions and influences the performance of land models by limiting the quality and accuracy of the input data necessary for precise modeling.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty in verifying assimilated soil moisture data, particularly in regions with high variability in the spatial distribution of soil moisture?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty in verifying assimilated soil moisture data arises from the insufficient available ground-level observation data, large errors in observed soil moisture, and the inherent high variability of the spatial distribution of soil moisture. These factors collectively complicate the verification process by reducing the reliability and representativeness of the data used for comparison.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact on the temporal and spatial resolution of soil moisture data when using satellite remote sensing data versus ground-based observations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Soil moisture observations based on satellite remote sensing are problematic due to precision issues related to soil type, ground surface roughness, and vegetation coverage, resulting in inversion errors and insufficient temporal and spatial resolutions. In contrast, soil moisture obtained through land hydrological modeling simulation has good temporal frequency and spatial distribution, but its precision is greatly influenced by model structure and input data.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the integration of high-resolution FY2C satellite data with NCEP reanalysis data influence the quality of atmospheric driving data in soil moisture studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of inverted precipitation and ground-incident solar radiation products acquired through high spatial and temporal resolution FY2C satellite data with NCEP reanalysis data was used to establish a set of high-quality atmospheric driving data covering the Chinese region. This integration aims to address the challenge of lacking long-term, high-resolution, observational atmospheric driving data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using different data assimilation methods like the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) for soil moisture data assimilation on the accuracy of soil moisture distribution predictions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) as an assimilation method in land model assimilation systems helps calculate predicted error covariance of the state, which can improve the precision of soil moisture distribution predictions. The assimilated soil moisture distribution has been shown to match well with observed soil moisture, reflecting reasonably the temporal-spatial distribution and aligning with actual drought conditions in certain regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to integrate satellite-derived precipitation estimates with ground observation data to improve spatial distribution accuracy in atmospheric datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The integration involves using multi-channel data from geostationary satellites to estimate 6-hour accumulated precipitation and merging these estimates with conventional ground observation data. High-resolution cloud classification information is then used to determine interpolation weights for converting 6-hour accumulated precipitation into 1-hour estimates.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in the downscaling of NCEP reanalysis data to achieve high temporal and spatial resolution atmospheric driving datasets for regional applications?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The downscaling process involves applying spatial and temporal interpolation methods to the original 1.0°×1.0° NCEP reanalysis data. This interpolation results in atmospheric driving datasets with a higher resolution of 0.1°×0.1° and an hourly temporal resolution, which includes variables such as near-surface temperature, relative humidity, surface pressure, and wind speed.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques enable the generation of high-resolution atmospheric driving datasets over China?
Enablement.Answer: The generation of high-resolution atmospheric driving datasets over China is enabled by the integration of geostationary satellite data, such as the Chinese Fengyun-2 series, with reanalysis data. For instance, precipitation data is derived by merging 6-hour cumulative precipitation estimates from the satellite with ground observations and applying high-resolution cloud classification for temporal interpolation. Solar radiation data is calculated using the DISORT radiative transfer model based on FY-2C satellite data.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in satellite remote sensing enhance the accuracy and spatial resolution of atmospheric driving data?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in satellite remote sensing, such as the use of high spatial and temporal resolution data from the FY-2C geostationary satellite, enhance the accuracy and spatial resolution of atmospheric driving data by providing detailed cloud classification information and radiative transfer calculations. This allows for precise determination of solar radiation and precipitation rates at a fine spatial resolution of 0.1°×0.1° and temporal resolution of 1 hour.

Expectation.Question: Why might the precision of soil moisture inversion from satellite remote sensing be problematic, and what factors contribute to this issue?
Expectation.Answer: The precision of soil moisture inversion from satellite remote sensing can be problematic due to factors such as soil type, ground surface roughness, and vegetation coverage. The uncertainty in these parameters results in inversion errors and insufficient temporal and spatial resolutions.

Expectation.Question: What challenges are faced in improving the precision of land model simulations, particularly in relation to atmospheric driving data?
Expectation.Answer: One of the main challenges in improving the precision of land model simulations is the lack of long-term, high-resolution observational atmospheric driving data. This insufficiency affects the ability to accurately simulate land processes and interactions with the atmosphere.

Expectation.Question: Why is it difficult to verify assimilated soil moisture data, and what issues are associated with ground-level observation soil moisture data?
Expectation.Answer: It is difficult to verify assimilated soil moisture data due to the insufficient availability of ground-level observation soil moisture data and the large errors in observed soil moisture. Additionally, the high spatial variability of soil moisture also contributes to the verification challenges.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in using satellite remote sensing for soil moisture data collection, especially in terms of precision and resolution?
Judgmental.Answer: Satellite remote sensing for soil moisture data collection faces challenges related to precision due to factors like soil type, surface roughness, and vegetation coverage. These parameters can introduce inversion errors, while the resolution might be insufficient to capture detailed spatial and temporal variations, impacting the reliability of the data for ecological and hydrological research.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure why the lack of long-term, high-resolution observational atmospheric driving data is such a big challenge in this area.
Assertion.Answer: The lack of long-term, high-resolution observational atmospheric driving data poses a significant challenge because it limits the ability to accurately simulate and model land-atmosphere interactions. High-resolution data are essential for understanding fine-scale atmospheric processes and for improving the precision of land model simulations, which are crucial for various environmental and agricultural applications.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data fusion process used to estimate precipitation rates by combining satellite data and ground-based observations.
Request/Directive.Answer: The precipitation rate estimation involves using 6-hour accumulated precipitation estimates derived from China's Fengyun-2 (FY-2) geostationary satellite multi-channel data and fusing them with conventional ground-based observations. This fusion process produces spatial distribution data of 6-hour accumulated precipitation. High-resolution cloud classification information from the satellite data is then used to determine the temporal interpolation weights, resulting in 1-hour accumulated precipitation estimates.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explain the challenges in improving soil moisture data precision and how data assimilation methods address these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in improving soil moisture data precision include the lack of long-term, high-resolution observational atmospheric driving data, the large error in observed soil moisture, and the high variability in soil moisture's spatial distribution. Data assimilation methods like the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) are employed to address these challenges by integrating satellite data with ground-based observations and model simulations to enhance the accuracy and consistency of soil moisture datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the methods and datasets used for generating high-resolution atmospheric driving data for land model simulations.
Request/Directive.Answer: The generation of high-resolution atmospheric driving data involves using FY2C satellite data to obtain inverted precipitation and ground-incident solar radiation products with high spatial and temporal resolution. These products are combined with NCEP reanalysis data to create quality atmospheric driving data for China. The data include variables such as atmospheric temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, atmospheric pressure, and precipitation, as well as surface short-wave radiation and soil moisture data.
